question: 2 (c)
statement_html:
Suppose that you want to solve the boundary value problem

\[\begin{aligned} f''(x) - x^2f(x) = 1, \quad 0 \leq x \leq 1, \quad f(0) = 1, \quad f(1) = 1.\end{aligned}\]

Let \(\mathbf{F} = [f_0, f_1, \dots, f_N]^T\) be the finite difference approximation to the solution \(f\)(x) at uniformaly spaced points x0, x1, ..., xN.

(c) Suppose the boundary condition at x = 0 is changed to

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(0) = 1 - f'(0).\end{aligned}\]

How do A and b change in this case?
statement_latex:
Suppose that you want to solve the boundary value problem

\begin{align*}
f''(x) - x^2f(x) = 1, \quad 0 \leq x \leq 1, \quad f(0) = 1, \quad f(1) = 1.
\end{align*}

Let $\mathbf{F} = [f_0, f_1, \dots, f_N]^T$ be the finite difference
approximation to the solution \emph{$f$(x)} at uniformaly spaced points
\emph{x\textsubscript{0}}, \emph{x\textsubscript{1}}, ...,
\emph{x\textsubscript{N}}.

\textbf{(c)} Suppose the boundary condition at \emph{x = 0} is changed
to

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f(0) = 1 - f'(0).
\end{align*}

How do \emph{A} and \textbf{\emph{b}} change in this case?
statement_raw:
Suppose that you want to solve the boundary value problem

:<math>
f''(x) - x^2f(x) = 1, \quad 0 \leq x \leq 1, \quad f(0) = 1, \quad f(1) = 1.
</math>

Let <math>\mathbf{F} = [f_0, f_1, \dots, f_N]^T</math> be the finite difference approximation to the solution ''&fnof;(x)'' at uniformaly spaced points ''x<sub>0</sub>'', ''x<sub>1</sub>'', ..., ''x<sub>N</sub>''.

'''(c)''' Suppose the boundary condition at ''x = 0'' is changed to

:<math> \displaystyle
f(0) = 1 - f'(0).
</math>

How do ''A'' and '''''b''''' change in this case?
